citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The veterinarian was not consulted regarding the care of certain animals the facility had identified with a medical
condition.
- A ram was seen at the time of inspection with skin missing above his left eye with healing/scarring tissue underneath.
Per a facility representative, this injury was sustained a few months ago from a fight with another ram. The facility treated
with a topical salve but did not gain approval from the veterinarian for this mode of treatment.
- A white goat with a black posterior was seen with an enlarged, reddened right teat. The teat reached the floor and was
as big as one of the goat’s legs. The goat has not been nursing a kid for about 6 weeks (since February 25, 2024). The
facility did not treat or consult with the veterinarian on care for this goat.
- A female zebra was seen with an open bloody wound at the base of her tail. The wound was of significant size,
approximately 3 inches wide and 3.5 inches long, with the tissue beneath appearing pulverized. The licensee identified
this injury a few days ago but did not consult with the veterinarian on care.
When the attending veterinarian is not given the appropriate authority, the provision of veterinary care may be inadequate
or inappropriate. The licensee must assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the
provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use. Correct by
April 12, 2024.

The shelter for the camels located at the front of the facility provided protection from the sun and from the rain but did not
provide shelter from the wind or the cold. At the time of inspection, this was the only type of shelter provided to 3 pregnant
camels. Inappropriate shelter against wind or cold may impact the camels’ health and comfort. Shelter appropriate to the
local climatic conditions must be provided for all animals kept outdoors to afford them protection. Correct by April 17,
2024.

A dead decomposing chicken was found behind and in between the stored hay bales. Bird feathers were also seen in
front of and propped against another hay bale. This hay is used both for rhea bedding and to feed hoof stock. This food
and bedding storage area has been contaminated by dead bird pest. Supplies of food and bedding must be stored in a
manner that protects the supplies from deterioration, contamination, and vermin infestation. Dead animals not intended for
food must not be kept in food storage areas. Correct by April 17, 2024.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 ore inspections or by June 8, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
